facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 687 of 1962 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 687 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated December 1, 1961 of Punjab High Court at Chandigarh in Execution Second Appeal No. 586 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal -by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 1, 1961, of the Punjab High Court at Chandigarh, in Execution Second Appeal No. 586 of 1960.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 20, 1963 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. February 20. The judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This appeal with the special leave of this Court arises out of execution of a decree for pre-emption passed in favour of the appellant Jang Singh.

facts.text: Appeal arises out of execution of a decree for pre-emption passed in favour of appellant Jang Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This appeal with the special leave of this Court arises out of execution of a decree for pre-emption passed in favour of the appellant Jang Singh.

facts.text: Punjab High Court held that Jang Singh had not deposited the full amount as directed by the decree within the time allowed, so suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: By the order under appeal the High Court has held that jang Singh had number deposited the full amount as directed by the decree within the time allowed to him and his suit for pre-emption must therefore be ordered to be dismissed and also the other proceedings arising therefrom as there was numberdecree -of which he companyld ask execution.

facts.text: Jang Singh filed suit for pre-emption of sale of certain lands against Brij Lal (first respondent, vendor) and Bhola Singh (second respondent, vendee) in Court of Sub-judge 1st Class, Sirsa.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case are simple. Jang Singh filed a suit for pre-emption of the sale of certain lands against Brij Lal the first respondent  the vendor , and Bhola Singh the second respondent  the vendee  in the Court of Sub-judge 1st Class, Sirsa.

facts.text: On October 25, 1957, compromise decree passed in favour of Jang Singh directing deposit of Rs. 5951 less Rs. 1000 already deposited (i.e., Rs. 4951) by May 1, 1958, failing which suit dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: On October 25, 1957, a companypromise decree was passed in favour of jang Singh and he was directed to deposit Rs. 5951 less Rs. 1000 already deposited by him by May 1, 1958. The decree also ordered that on his failing to make the deposit punctually his suit would stand dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: On January 6, 1958, Jang Singh made application to Sub-judge Sirsa for deposit of balance amount.

anchor.surface_text: On January 6, 1958, jang Singh made an application to the Sub judge, Sirsa, for making the deposit of the balance of the amount of the decree.

facts.text: Court clerk prepared challan mentioning Rs. 4950 instead of Rs. 4951, handed to Jang Singh who deposited Rs. 4950 same day and received acknowledgement from Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The Clerk of the Court, which was also the executing Court, prepared a challan in duplicate and handed it over with the application to jang Singh so that the amount might be deposited in the Bank. In the challan  and in the order passed on the application, so it is alleged  Rs. 4950 were mentioned instead of Rs. 4951. jang Singh took the challan and the application and made the deposit of the wrong balance the same day and received one companyy of the challan as an acknowledgement from the Bank.

facts.text: In May 1958, Jang Singh applied for and received order for possession of the land.

anchor.surface_text: In May, 1958, he applied for and received an order for possession of the land.

facts.text: Naib Nazir reported that entire amount was deposited in court.

anchor.surface_text: It was reported by the Naib Nazir that the entire amount was deposited in Court.

facts.text: On May 25, 1958, Bhola Singh applied for payment of amount in deposit; Naib Nazir reported deposit short by one rupee.

anchor.surface_text: Bhola Singh then applied on May 25, 1958, to the Court for payment to him of the amount lying in deposit and it was reported by the Naib Nazir on that application that Jang Singh had number deposited the companyrect amount and the deposit was short by one rupee.

facts.text: Bhola Singh applied for dismissal of Jang Singh's suit and recall of orders in his favour.

anchor.surface_text: Bhola Singh applied to the Court for dismissal of jang Singhs suit, and for recall of all the orders made in jang Singhs favour.

facts.text: Sub-judge Sirsa accepted Bhola Singh's application, dismissed suit observing no power to extend time in pre-emption cases, reversed earlier orders, restored possession to opposite party.

anchor.surface_text: The Sub Judge, Sirsa, accepted Bhola Singhsapplication observing that in pre-emption cases a Court had numberpower to extend the time fixed by the decree for payment of the price and the preemptor by his failure to deposit the companyrect amount had incurred the dismissal of the suit under the decree. He ordered also the reversal of the earlier orders passed by him in favour of Jang Singh and directed that possession of the fields be restored to the opposite party.

facts.text: Jang Singh appealed to District Judge against Sub-judge's order.

anchor.surface_text: jang Singh appealed against that order.

facts.text: District Judge recorded evidence of Execution Clerk, Revenue Accountant, Treasury officer, Jang Singh, and examined Bhola Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The District judge recorded the evidence of the Execution Clerk, the Revenue Accountant, Treasury ice and jang Singh. He also examined Bhola Singh.

facts.text: District Judge held Jang Singh not present when decree passed, did not know exact amount; court and clerk mistake in challan, responsibility shared, deposit sufficient compliance, set aside Sub-judge order.

anchor.surface_text: the learned District judge held that the record of the case showed that on the day the case was companypromised and the decree was passed Jang Singh was number present and did number know the exact decretal amount. ... The learned District Judge, therefore, held that this was a case in which jang Singh deserved to be relieved and he came to the companyclusion that jang Singh was prevented from depositing the full amount by the act of the Court. He companycluded thus the deposit made was a sufficient companypliance with the terms of the decree. The order of the Sub Judge, Sirsa dismissing the suit was set aside.

facts.text: Bhola Singh appealed to Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Bhola Singh appealed to the High Court.

facts.text: High Court single judge held decree not complied with, no power to extend time, finding of court act unsupported by evidence, set aside District Judge decision, restored Sub-judge order.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal was heard by a learned single.judge who was of the opinion that the decree which was passed was number companyplied with and that under the law the time fixed under the decree for the payment of the decretal amount in pre-emption cases companyld number be extended by the Court. He also held that the finding that the short deposit was due to an act of the Court was unsupported by evidence. He accordingly set aside the decision of the learned District judge and restored that of the Sub-judge, Sirsa.

facts.text: Challan prepared by court showing Rs. 4950, duplicate challan produced, Jang Singh is illiterate person.

anchor.surface_text: A search was made for the application on which the order of the Court directing a deposit of Rs. 4950 was said to be passed. ... This challan is admittedly prepared by the Execution Clerk and it is also an admitted fact that Jang Singh is an illiterate person.

facts.text: Execution Clerk deposed to usual procedure: report on amount, court order, then challan.

anchor.surface_text: The Execution Clerk has deposed to the procedure which is usually followed and he has pointed out that first there is a report by the Ahmed about the amount in deposit and then an order is made by the Court on the application before the challan is prepared.

facts.text: Supreme Court held court and officers contributed to error in amount.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, quite clear that if there was an error the Court and its officers largely companytributed to it.

facts.text: Jang Singh illiterate.

anchor.surface_text: it is also an admitted fact that Jang Singh is an illiterate person.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court decision, ordered Jang Singh to deposit Re.1 within one month from receipt of record in Sub-judge Sirsa court, failing which suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the decision of the learned single judge of the High Court must be set aside. ... The appellant is ordered to deposit Re.1 within one month from the date of the receipt of the record in the Court of the Sub-judge, Sirsa.

facts.text: Parties relegated to position on January 6, 1958 when error committed by court.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the mistake of the Court which needs to be righted the parties are relegated to the position they occupied on January 6, 1958, when the error was companymitted by the Court which error is being rectified by us nunc pro tune.
Appeal -by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 1, 1961, of the Punjab High Court at Chandigarh, in Execution Second Appeal No. 586 of 1960.
This appeal with the special leave of this Court arises out of execution of a decree for pre-emption passed in favour of the appellant Jang Singh.

It is nodoubt true that a litigant must be vigilant and take care but where a litigant goes to Court and asks for the assistance of the Court so that his obligation-, under a decree might be fulfilled by him strictly, it is incumbent on the Court, if it does number leave the litigant to his own devices, to ensure that the companyrect information is furnished. If the Court in supplying the information makes a mistake the responsibility of the litigant, though it does number altogether cease, is at least shared by the Court. If the litigant acts on the faith of that information the Courts cannot hold him responsible for a mistake which it itself caused. There is numberhigher principle for the guidance of the Court than the one that numberact of Courts should harm a litigant and it is the bounden duty of Courts to see that if a person is harmed by a mistake of the Court he should be restored to the position he would have occupied but for that mistake. This is aptly summed up in the maxim Actus curiae neminem gravabit.

concepts.interpretation: No act of court should harm a litigant; courts must restore a litigant harmed by a court mistake to the position they would have occupied but for that mistake.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: k has deposed to the procedure which is usually followed and he has pointed out that first there is a report by the Ahmed about the amount in deposit

concepts.unlisted_description: Latin maxim meaning 'an act of the court shall prejudice no one'; applied to rectify court errors harming litigants.

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule that courts cannot extend time fixed in pre-emption decrees for deposit of purchase money.

anchor.surface_text: We may point out however that we are number deciding the question whether a Court after passing a decree for re-emption can extend the time originally fixed for deposit of the decretal amount. That question does number arise here.

anchor.surface_text: It is nodoubt true that a litigant must be vigilant and take care but where a litigant goes to Court and asks for the assistance of the Court so that his obligation-, under a decree might be fulfilled by him strictly, it is incumbent on the Court, if it does number leave the litigant to his own devices, to ensure that the companyrect information is furnished. If the Court in supplying the information makes a mistake the responsibility of the litigant, though it does number altogether cease, is at least shared by the Court. If the litigant acts on the faith of that information the Courts cannot hold him responsible for a mistake which it itself caused. There is numberhigher principle for the guidance of the Court than the one that numberact of Courts should harm a litigant and it is the bounden duty of Courts to see that if a person is harmed by a mistake of the Court he should be restored to the position he would have occupied but for that mistake. This is aptly summed up in the maxim Actus curiae neminem gravabit.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was correct in reversing the District Judge's finding that the short deposit was due to the court's error in reporting the amount and preparing the challan

anchor.surface_text: The learned single judge of the High Court companysidered the case as if it was one of extension of time. He reversed the finding given by the District Judge that the application made by Jang Singh did number mention any amount and the ice reported that only Rs. 4950 were due. The learned single judge exceeded his jurisdiction there. It is quite clear that once the finding of the District judge is accepted-and it proceeds on evidence given by jang Singh and the Execution Clerk-the only companyclusion that can be reached is that jang Singh relied upon what the Court ordered and the error, if any, was substantially the making of the Court. In these circumstances, following the well-accepted principle that the act of Court should harm numberone, the District Judge was right in reversing the decision of the Sub. Judge, Sirsa.

holdings.text: If there was an error the Court and its officers largely contributed to it.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, quite clear that if there was an error the Court and its officers largely companytributed to it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows challan prepared by court clerk under court direction after report on amount; usual procedure followed; illiterate litigant relied on it.

holdings.text: No higher principle than that no act of Courts should harm a litigant; bounden duty of Courts to restore person harmed by mistake of Court to position but for that mistake; summed up in maxim Actus curiae neminem gravabit.

anchor.surface_text: There is no higher principle for the guidance of the Court than the one that no act of Courts should harm a litigant and it is the bounden duty of Courts to see that if a person is harmed by a mistake of the Court he should be restored to the position he would have occupied but for that mistake. This is aptly summed up in the maxim Actus curiae neminem gravabit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Litigant sought court assistance for strict compliance; court bound to furnish correct information; if court errs, shares responsibility; litigant acting in faith cannot be blamed; maxim guides to rectify harm.

holdings.text: Learned single judge of High Court considered case as extension of time and exceeded jurisdiction by reversing District Judge's finding on evidence that Jang Singh's application mentioned no amount and officer reported Rs.4950 due.

anchor.surface_text: The learned single judge of the High Court considered the case as if it was one of extension of time. He reversed the finding given by the District Judge that the application made by Jang Singh did not mention any amount and the officer reported that only Rs. 4950 were due. The learned single judge exceeded his jurisdiction there.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual finding based on evidence of Jang Singh and Execution Clerk; High Court mischaracterized case and improperly interfered with facts.

holdings.text: Following principle that act of Court should harm no one, District Judge was right in reversing Sub-Judge Sirsa.

anchor.surface_text: It is quite clear that once the finding of the District judge is accepted-and it proceeds on evidence given by Jang Singh and the Execution Clerk-the only conclusion that can be reached is that Jang Singh relied upon what the Court ordered and the error, if any, was substantially the making of the Court. In these circumstances, following the well-accepted principle that the act of Court should harm no one, the District Judge was right in reversing the decision of the Sub. Judge, Sirsa.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court error in amount; shared responsibility; principle requires not harming litigant due to court act.

holdings.text: District Judge in error holding decree sufficiently complied with; could only be fully complied with by deposit of Re.1 which District Judge ought to have ordered.

anchor.surface_text: The District judge was, however, in error in holding that the decree was sufficiently complied with. That decree could only be fully complied with by making the deposit of Re. 1 which the District judge ought to have ordered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree terms require full exact amount; short deposit not compliance despite court error; opportunity to cure must be given.

holdings.text: Decision of High Court single judge set aside; appellant ordered to deposit Re.1 within one month from receipt of record in Sub-judge Sirsa court, failing which suit dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the decision of the learned single judge of the High Court must be set aside. ... The appellant is ordered to deposit Re.1 within one month from the date of the receipt of the record in the Court of the Sub-judge, Sirsa.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rectify court mistake; not dismissal without chance to deposit balance; applies act of court principle.

holdings.text: Parties relegated to position on January 6, 1958 when error committed by Court, rectified nunc pro tunc.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the mistake of the Court which needs to be righted the parties are relegated to the position they occupied on January 6, 1958, when the error was committed by the Court which error is being rectified by us nunc pro tunc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court mistake needs righting; restore status quo ante error with retrospective effect.

holdings.text: Not deciding whether Court after pre-emption decree can extend time fixed for deposit of decretal amount; question does not arise.

anchor.surface_text: We may point out however that we are not deciding the question whether a Court after passing a decree for pre-emption can extend the time originally fixed for deposit of the decretal amount. That question does not arise here.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Case concerns rectification of court error, not extension of time.

anchor.surface_text: panyld ask execution. The facts of the case are simple. Jang Singh filed a suit for pre-emption of the sale of certain lands against Brij Lal the firs

edges.explanation: Punjab High Court holding not deposited within time grounds the argument for dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, quite clear that if there was an error the Court and its officers largely companytributed to it.
The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The appellant is ordered to deposit Re.1 within one month from the date of the receipt of the record in the Court of the Sub-judge, Sirsa.

There is no higher principle for the guidance of the Court than the one that no act of Courts should harm a litigant and it is the bounden duty of Courts to see that if a person is harmed by a mistake of the Court he should be restored to the position he would have occupied but for that mistake. This is aptly summed up in the maxim Actus curiae neminem gravabit.
The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The appellant is ordered to deposit Re.1 within one month from the date of the receipt of the record in the Court of the Sub-judge, Sirsa.

The learned single judge of the High Court considered the case as if it was one of extension of time. He reversed the finding given by the District Judge that the application made by Jang Singh did not mention any amount and the officer reported that only Rs. 4950 were due. The learned single judge exceeded his jurisdiction there.
The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The appellant is ordered to deposit Re.1 within one month from the date of the receipt of the record in the Court of the Sub-judge, Sirsa.

It is quite clear that once the finding of the District judge is accepted-and it proceeds on evidence given by Jang Singh and the Execution Clerk-the only conclusion that can be reached is that Jang Singh relied upon what the Court ordered and the error, if any, was substantially the making of the Court. In these circumstances, following the well-accepted principle that the act of Court should harm no one, the District Judge was right in reversing the decision of the Sub. Judge, Sirsa.
The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The appellant is ordered to deposit Re.1 within one month from the date of the receipt of the record in the Court of the Sub-judge, Sirsa.

The District judge was, however, in error in holding that the decree was sufficiently complied with. That decree could only be fully complied with by making the deposit of Re. 1 which the District judge ought to have ordered.
The appeal is, therefore, allowed. The appellant is ordered to deposit Re.1 within one month from the date of the receipt of the record in the Court of the Sub-judge, Sirsa.

edges.explanation: The holding sets aside the High Court decision and orders deposit of Re.1 with consequence of dismissal, directly addressing whether the deposit was made within time to avoid dismissal of the pre-emption suit.
